articles.author: Release notes from osmosfeed
articles.description:
Added: Atom feed generator
Added: Customizable site title
Added: Copy all files from static directory to the root of the site.
Changed: Favicon, css, and js assets now existing at site root level.
Chore: Excluded testing files from repo.
articles.title: v1.5.0

articles.description: Added: Basic theme customization: Demo | Source. See documentation.
articles.title: v1.4.0

articles.description:
Fixed: Avoid crwalers.
Fixed: Error logging from XML parser.
Fixed: Typo in docs.
Thank you: @dym-sh, @tabokie, @cheese1
articles.title: v1.3.1

articles.description:
Added: Customize cache lifespan with cacheMaxDays property in osmosfeed.yaml.
Added: Documentation for osmosfeed.yaml.
Fixed: More intuitive logging during build.
Chore: Refactored parameter passing for enrich step.
articles.title: v1.3.0

articles.description: Changed: favicon update.
articles.title: v1.2.3

articles.description: Added: Display CLI version in footer.
articles.title: v1.2.1

articles.description: Fixed: The output website didn't have favicon.
articles.title: v1.1.6

articles.description: Fixed: Item description didn't use the description property from feed item.
articles.title: v1.1.1

articles.description:
Added: MIT license
Added: cache.json is stamped with the version of the builder. This allows future builder with breaking change to ignore incompatible cache.
Added: Feed source retry on fetch error (3 times total, 15 seconds timeout).
Added: Item enrichment retry on fetch error (3 times total, 15 seconds timeout).
Added: Console log for cache restore and update behavior.
Added: npx command: npx osmosfeed
Changed: Improved console log that breaks down rendered item count into "new" and "cached".
Fixed: Item…
articles.title: v1.1.0

articles.description:
Changed: Runtime dependencies are moved out of devDependencies. This is not a breaking change, but to receive performance benefit, you need to make sure @osmoscraft/osmosfeed is listed as dependencies instead of devDependencies in the package.json of your rss reader site.
Changed: Build target from node12 to node14.
Changed: Switched to a more robust rss parser: rss-parser
Fixed: RSS 1.0 feed <dc:date> was not parsed as publish date.
Chore: npm dependencies version updates.
articles.title: v1.0.1

articles.description:
We have been hard at work building new experimental features for the Windows Package Manager. We have just released the Windows Package Manager v0.3 Preview. I would like to share the first major feature to exit experimental status. I also have the privilege of announcing support for Group Policy.
The post Windows Package Manager v0.3 Preview appeared first on Windows Command Line.
articles.title: Windows Package Manager v0.3 Preview

articles.description:
A year ago at BUILD 2020 we introduced our goal to bring Linux GUI applications to the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) to run Linux GUI applications. We are proud to announce the first preview of this highly anticipated and open source feature!
The post The Initial Preview of GUI app support is now available for the Windows Subsystem for Linux appeared first on Windows Command Line.
articles.title: The Initial Preview of GUI app support is now available for the Windows Subsystem for Linux

articles.description:
If you landed on this blog, you’ve probably seen our announcement for GUI applications support in the Windows Subsystem for Linux being available to Windows Insiders and looking for more details on how WSLg was built. If so, you’ve come to the right place!
The post WSLg Architecture appeared first on Windows Command Line.
articles.title: WSLg Architecture

articles.description:
Note: This blog post is co-authored by the awesome WSL dev Pierre Boulay. Thanks Pierre! 😊
The post Servicing the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) 2 Linux kernel appeared first on Windows Command Line.
articles.title: Servicing the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) 2 Linux kernel

articles.description:
Welcome back to another release of Windows Terminal! This release updates Windows Terminal Preview to version 1.8 and moves Windows Terminal to version 1.7. Both builds can be installed from the Microsoft Store as well as the GitHub releases page. Let’s jump into what’s new!
The post Windows Terminal Preview 1.8 Release appeared first on Windows Command Line.
articles.title: Windows Terminal Preview 1.8 Release

articles.description: Last month, I climbed Cerro Zapaleri, the 5648 m tall summit of which forms the tripoint of the borders of Chile, Argentina, and Bolivia.1 Its location is quite remote, ~105 km from San Pedro de Atacama, Chile and >40 km from the nearest … Continue reading →
articles.title: Climbing Cerro Zapaleri

articles.description: “Good friends, good books, and a sleepy conscience: this is the ideal life.” ― Mark TwainI hope you’re reading this blog in your pjs looking forward to a rejuvenating and healthy weekend.  I have been working on multiple projects lately, from creating Machine Learing Engineering and Machine Learning Operations courses
articles.title: Machine Learning Systems Book Recommendations – Learn How to Build and Understand ML Systems

articles.description: Any concept that we don't fully understand can be scary at first. Recursion is a topic that programming students don't learn right away. articles.description: Here is a simple and practical example what it means to "lift state up" in React, and how it can help you build your applications. Lifting state up is a common pattern that is essential for React developers to know. It helps you avoid more complex (and often unnecessary) patterns
articles.title: What Is "Lifting State Up" in React?

articles.title: Learn How to Use the Chrome DevTools to Troubleshoot Websites

articles.title: Optional Types in Swift – How to Use and Unwrap Optionals

articles.title: Python and OpenCV Course –Create Computer Vision Apps in the Cloud

articles.title: Node.js Async Await Tutorial – With Asynchronous JavaScript Examples

articles.description: To copy files or directories in Unix-based operating systems (Linux and MacOS), you use the cp command. The cp command is a relatively simple command, but its behavior changes slightly depending on the inputs (files vs directories) and the options you pass to it. To view the documentation or manual
articles.title: Copy a Directory in Linux – How to cp a Folder in the Command Line in Linux and Unix (MacOS)
